report_title: Glass & Glazing Contractors in the US
executive_summary: Glass and glazing contractors install glass curtain walls, windows, doors, room dividers and other products in residential, commercial and institutional buildings. Glass windows and structures are key components of construction projects. A significant portion of industry revenue is derived from work on office spaces, and commercial and institutional buildings, with the remainder coming from residential markets.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Nonresidential Construction Suffers Amid Shutdowns and Economic Strife
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Nonresidential construction covers work performed on hotels, office buildings, stores, restaurants, commercial warehouses, institutional buildings and manufacturing facilities. The COVID-19 pandemic significantly halted activity within the nonresidential building market and forced businesses to revise construction plans amid the plummeting economy. Establishments and operations were forced to close to curtail the spread of the virus. This resulted in historical levels of unemployment, a decrease in consumer spending and a general decline in overall economic activity. Nonresidential construction activity will continue declining in 2023 as work in this sector takes longer to improve post-recession.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Residential Construction Activity Booms Amid Low Interest Rates
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The residential construction market covers work on single and multi-family homes and apartment buildings. To stimulate the stagnant economy, the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates to curtail the negative effects of the COVID-19-induced recession. Mortgage rates followed suit and were lowered as well. This greatly benefited the industry's secondary market, residential construction, since home building and renovation projects take a relatively short amount of time to complete and are highly susceptible and responsive to the price of financing.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Institutional Building Construction Activity Has Risen Despite COVID Restrictions
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Institutional building construction, consisting of government-owned buildings such as schools, universities and hospitals, has modestly grown compared with other forms of nonresidential building. These structures provide significant demand for interior and exterior glass and glazing services, especially within the hospital segment due to heightened demand amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Though in conjunction with tighter budgets, suspension of in-class learning and institutional employees working from home, some local governments curbed spending on new construction.

To offset the volatility in demand from new construction projects, glass and glazing contractors have increasingly focused on renovations and repair work. Retail shop owners and other commercial property owners, in addition to apartment building property managers, cannot delay glass repair if a building's glass front or window is damaged, making repair services somewhat resistant to broader economic conditions.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Glass and Glazing Contractors Industry Will Encounter Fluctuating Performance
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: - The economy will stabilize and recover from the COVID-19 pandemic and activity in most sectors will increase. - Many businesses will take advantage of the new business cycle, beginning new nonresidential projects and supporting industry growth. - But at the same time, the Federal Reserve will increase interest rates and this is already evident in the current year with the substantial mortgage rate hikes. - The gradual increase in the price of financing is projected to hamper activity within the residential construction market. Still, the industry will remain shielded since activity within the nonresidential construction market is a larger determinant of industry performance compared with residential construction.

The nonresidential construction market will recuperate through the end of 2028 as the economy recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic. The key segments of the nonresidential construction market include office and commercial space expansion, which will be lifted by restored business sentiment and hospital and educational building construction, supported by expanding government budgets. Demand for glass exteriors will increase in many of these buildings, especially in commercial centers, along with decorative glass and mirrors for the interior. Remodeling and retrofit projects in commercial buildings are also expected to provide steady work for industry contractors.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising Interest Rates Will Hamper Residential Construction Activity
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the economy fully recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic and work in all sectors returns to normal levels, the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates to maintain a substantial level of economic growth. Since home building and renovation projects take a relatively short amount of time to complete, the level of activity within the residential building market is highly susceptible to the price of financing. As financing becomes more expensive, people are less likely to refinance and renovate their homes. Also, since the construction of new houses is more costly than making repairs for existing buildings, the increased cost of financing will be a larger detriment to new housing starts.

The push for more environmentally sustainable building designs and inputs will have mixed implications over the next five years. Some architects and environmental advocates have raised concerns regarding the energy efficiency of conventional floor-to-ceiling glass windows and curtain walls. The high level of sun exposure makes maintaining a steady interior climate expensive, raising energy usage for the structure and increasing tenants' utility costs. To regulate energy use, building designs may moderate use of curtain walls and window areas. If building designers decide to slowly incorporate less square footage of glass, it could produce less contract sizes and slow revenue growth.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry select, cut and install glass panels for large windows, glass doors, skylights, curtain walls and sunroom additions in all types of buildings; they also install window panes. The glasswork performed includes new work, additions, alterations, maintenance and repairs. This industry does not install, tint or repair automotive glass and it does not install prefabricated window units.

Nonresidential construction activity historically takes longer to improve post-recession and follows a lag of one to two years to that of the residential construction market. Commercial work continues to dwindle.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The largest market for glass and glazing contractors is nonresidential construction. Many high rises and office buildings use glass for exteriors and extensively require the services of glaziers and glass contractors. The industry is very sensitive to fluctuations in commercial and institutional building construction.

business_locations.location_description: This region houses the most industry establishments of any region. The region includes Florida which boasts several high-density, commercially developed cities including Miami, Orlando, Tampa and Jacksonville, among others. The hospitality market is particularly important to glass contractors in the state, which has a large tourism economy. Other notable metropolitan areas in the region include Charlotte, North Carolina and Atlanta, Georgia.

California has a concentration of establishments. Glass and glazing contractors choose to locate in the region due to the robust housing market. California is also home to populous metropolitan areas and commercial centers such as Los Angeles, San Jose, San Diego and San Francisco.

The region includes densely populated cities in New York and New Jersey, which provide a strong source of demand for residential construction. Skyscraper and curtain wall work is in high demand in New York City.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The standards and codes applicable to this industry have been formulated with the participation of the Glazing Industry Codes Committee (GICC), which is a collaborative glass and glazing industry organization with the mission of promoting the correct use of glass and fenestration (fenestration is any opening in a building's envelope including windows, doors and skylights).

Building codes relating to glazing services are endorsed by the International Code Council (ICC), an umbrella organization consisting of the three regional model code groups in the US: The Southern Building Code Congress International (SBCCI), the Building Officials and Code Administrators (BOCA) and the International Conference of Code Officials (ICBO). The ICC publishes an International Building Code (IBC), an International Residential Code (IRC), and specific codes covering services such as electrical and plumbing.

The industry is subject to a building code published in 2002 by the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA 5000). The GICC was represented on NFPA 5000, including a glass and glazing chapter. GICC's aim is to ensure consistency between the IBC and NFPA 5000 to ensure the requirements for the glass and glazing industry do not vary between geographic markets.

The American National Standards Institute (ANSI) standard E2112-01 Standard Practice for installation of Exterior Windows, Doors and Skylights covers installing fenestration products in new and existing construction. The standard attempts to educate the installer, builder, architect and other users in the identification and understanding of the water shedding system of the building envelope and sets out the minimum requirements to accomplish the installation of fenestration products effectively.

In response to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidance, various levels of regulation have been implemented in the United States and overseas to discourage public gatherings, large events or crowded, unsafe work environments. Restrictions are easing in 2023 due to the widespread distribution of the COVID-19 vaccine.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Glass and glazing contractors are highly localized. No single contractor currently accounts for a market share of more than 5.0%.
Industry market share concentration is expected to remain low as most contractors continue to cater to local demand.
Industry concentration is growing somewhat, not by virtue of acquisitions, but because existing large-scale businesses are positioned to continue capturing high-revenue builds.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases have increased over the past five years. Inputs include processed flat glass, timber and aluminum joinery and fasteners and other materials such as plastics, granite, marble and other glass substitutes. Films or laminates that improve the durability or safety of the glass are also frequently purchased. All expenditure on subcontracted labor is included in purchase costs.

Profit has decreased over the past five years. Even though contractors were forced to reduce prices amid COVID-induced construction slowdowns, a minor reduction in labor costs has mitigated profit losses.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Skilled Labor is Highly Important, Resulting in High Wage Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages have decreased over the past five years. Glass and glazing contracting is highly labor-intensive, containing well-compensated architects and engineers that design cladding and curtain walls. Contractors also feature specialized work crews and subcontractors that perform the installation.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Glass and glazing contract work is highly labor-intensive. Contractors may also need specialists, such as architects and engineers, to design and execute specialized services, such as cladding and curtain walls.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Similar to most industries driven by the construction cycle, glasswork contractors are exposed to fluctuations in the real estate market. Volatility is somewhat mitigated by repair and maintenance work, which is more stable than new construction and alterations.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC SIGNIFICANTLY HAMPERED THE NONRESIDENTIAL CONSTRUCTION MARKET
volatility_points.volatility_description: Business activity plunged in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, resulting in a significant curtailment in nonresidential construction projects. Though the resumption of economic activity and curtailment of restrictions will enable the industry to recover and grow. Volatility will minimize over the next five years as nonresidential construction markets tepidly recover from the global health crisis.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The emergence of new types of glass products for installation in buildings has contributed to the increasing popularity of glass content in building construction. Glass products that have gained wide market acceptance over the past decade include the following: frameless suspended toughened glass, dual-

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: NEW PRODUCTS LEAD TO NEW SKILLS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The new technologies associated with structures such as curtain walls have required operators to develop the skills necessary to compete in this market segment. These new skills also include the ability to customize these increasingly sophisticated glass structures to suit client needs. Contractors that achieve recognition for the craftsmanship of their work are better positioned to secure future construction projects.

FAQs.question: Does your company primarily work with residential or non-residential construction markets?
FAQs.answer: Contractors in the Glass and Glazing industry primarily work with residential and nonresidential construction clients and can switch between these markets, depending on the size of their operations. Maintaining a mix of business in both markets can help protect revenue and profit against downturns in any single market. However, nonresidential construction accounts for a larger share of industry demand.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your operations are solely focused on new work? Do you participate in remodeling activities?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators provide glasswork services during new construction activities as well as during residential and commercial remodels. Providing services to both markets is important since demand for industry services from new construction work typically suffers during economic slowdowns while remodeling and repair word tend to fluctuate less significantly.

FAQs.question: How does your company compete for contracts with larger businesses? Do you ever find you lack the capacity to deliver on larger and more lucrative projects?
FAQs.answer: Most large operators in the industry compete on the basis of quality, especially for lucrative contracts with large projects. These operators typically do not lack the capacity to deliver on more lucrative projects.

FAQs.question: What is the size of your staff? How does that compare to your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Most contractors are nonemployers or operators with few employees that work mainly with home repairs and window installation, while bigger operators focus on larger contracts to install curtainwalls on city buildings.

FAQs.question: Have productivity issues ever kept you from winning lucrative contracts over larger competitors?
FAQs.answer: Lucrative contracts are typically awarded to larger contractors that have the resources to complete a quality job in a specific time for the right price.

FAQs.question: How much does your company invest in new equipment annually?
FAQs.answer: Depreciation is very low in this industry, accounting for less than 1.0% of industry revenue annually.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted your company's profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Regulatory expenses have not significantly impacted company profitability, but industry participants are required to hold licenses to carry out business within each state and territory, which can slightly increase costs.

FAQs.question: Do you work with local or national trade associations to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The National Glass Association (NGA) provides training and certification for members, organizes conferences and publishes research on the industry.

FAQs.question: How many of your clients are return customers?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators do not have many return customers, but rather referrals by clients they have serviced.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare to that of your closest competitor?
FAQs.answer: Profitability varies depending on the price of inputs and construction demand. Smaller operators tend to have lower profit, while larger contractors that accept more lucrative contracts typically experience wider margin.

FAQs.question: Do you have contacts with key distributors and end-users? What proportion of sales is derived from repeat customers, such as general contractors?
FAQs.answer: Establishing business relationships with general contractors and property developers in residential and commercial markets is essential for success in this industry. These markets are a large constituent of industry demand via repeat business.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a recognizable brand? How much does your company spend on advertising?
FAQs.answer: Emergency contract work is largely generated by brand recognition within a local market. Word-of-mouth referrals and having positive reviews on various internet platforms help build company awareness.

FAQs.question: How do you make sure your services or bids are attractive to potential customers? How effective is your company at competing on tender?
FAQs.answer: Most of the work in this industry is done on the basis of bidding. Successful operators need to be able to compete both in terms of price, quality and capability, while also maintaining adequate profit.

FAQs.question: How do you plan to mitigate the threat of rising interest rates for home purchasers? How much of your business is residential?
FAQs.answer: As the 30-year conventional mortgage rate increases, so does the borrowing cost associated with purchasing a home.

FAQs.question: Is your company able to improve sales along with increases in consumer spending? What measures will you take to promote industry services?
FAQs.answer: Expenditure on renovations increases with disposable income. Conversely, it falls with low disposable income, as households resort to do-it-yourself repairs and alterations instead of hiring a contractor.

FAQs.question: How would a decline in corporate profit affect demand for your company? How do you mitigate this threat?
FAQs.answer: Corporate profit for downstream businesses affects industry demand, as companies with higher profit are more enabled to purchase, upgrade and repair glass structures, such as windows and glass doors.
